xxl.core.xxlinq
Class AdvTupleCursor

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<Tuple>
      xxl.core.xxlinq.AdvTupleCursor
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Iterable<Tuple>, java.util.Iterator<Tuple>, Cursor<Tuple>, MetaDataCursor<Tuple,CompositeMetaData<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>>, MetaDataProvider<CompositeMetaData<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>>
public class AdvTupleCursor
extends AbstractCursor<Tuple>
implements MetaDataCursor<Tuple,CompositeMetaData<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>>, java.lang.Iterable<Tuple>

A Cursor wrapping another Cursor/Iterator/Iterable to a Tuple Cursor with AdvResultSetMetaData and CompositeMetaData. The central class of "LINQ for XXL" with join, union, where, select, etc as methods.

Nested Class Summary
static class AdvTupleCursor.CachingStrategy
          The Caching-Strategy to be used in a query's AdvTupleCursors:
ALL: Cache within all operators of a query NONE: Don't cache at all ONLY_FIRST: Only cache the first cursor so the Elements of the Input-Cursor don't have to be mapped to Tuples again after reset().
static class AdvTupleCursor.JOIN_TYPE
           
 
Field Summary
protected  boolean doNotCache
          If this is true, the tuples-List will not be used, i.e. the query will be re-evaluated after reset().
protected  boolean firstRun
          While this is true (and if caching isn't disabled) we will fill the tuples List on each next()

          true, if the cursor has already delivered an element (i.e. it's too late to change the caching strategy)

          If the tuples List is done (after first "run" of the cursor) this will be an iterator from it used in this cursors hasNextObject() and nextObject() methods.
protected  java.util.List<Tuple> tuples
          If caching isn't disabled, the elements of the wrapped Cursor will be mapped to AdvTuple and saved in this list.

protected java.util.List<Tuple> tuples

firstRun

protected boolean firstRun
While this is true (and if caching isn't disabled) we will fill the tuples List on each next()

inUse

protected boolean inUse
true, if the cursor has already delivered an element (i.e. it's too late to change the caching strategy)

tupleIt

protected java.util.Iterator<Tuple> tupleIt
If the tuples List is done (after first "run" of the cursor) this will be an iterator from it used in this cursors hasNextObject() and nextObject() methods. On reset() a new iterator is obtained from the list.

doNotCache

protected boolean doNotCache
If this is true, the tuples-List will not be used, i.e. the query will be re-evaluated after reset(). That is necessary if this is a (potentially correlated) subquery.

protected java.util.LinkedList<java.lang.reflect.Method> getters
Constructor Detail

AdvTupleCursor

public AdvTupleCursor(Cursor<?> cur,
                      Function<java.lang.Object,Tuple> mapping,
                      AdvResultSetMetaData metadata,
                      AdvTupleCursor... parents)
Constructor that takes an arbitrary Cursor, a Function that maps its Objects to Tuples, Metadata for the resulting tuples. If you want this Cursor to have a new alias, use AdvResultSetMetaData.clone(String newAlias) on your existing metadata.
Note: This is the constructor that is also be used, explicitly or via factorFromCursorWithTuples(), by our operators like join, select, where, ...

Parameters:
cur - some Cursor
mapping - Maps Objects from Cur to Tuple
metadata - Metadata appropriate for the resulting Tuples
parents - "parents" of this cursor (if any)

public AdvTupleCursor(Cursor<?> cur,

                      AdvResultSetMetaData metadata,
                      OperatorImplementation operatorImpl,
                      AdvTupleCursor... parents)
Constructor that takes an arbitrary Cursor, a Function that maps its Objects to Tuples, Metadata for the resulting tuples. If you want this Cursor to have a new alias, use AdvResultSetMetaData.clone(String newAlias) on your existing metadata.
Note: This is the constructor that is also be used, explicitly or via factorFromCursorWithTuples(), by our operators like join, select, where, ...

Parameters:
cur - some Cursor
mapping - Maps Objects from Cur to Tuple
metadata - Metadata appropriate for the resulting Tuples
operatorImpl - an implementation of operators, in case you want to provide your own (null for default operator - e.g. OperatorImplementation.getOperatorImpl() or the left parent's implementation, if any)
parents - "parents" of this cursor (if any)

public AdvTupleCursor(java.util.List<Tuple> list,
                      AdvResultSetMetaData metadata,
                      OperatorImplementation operImpl)

If you want this Cursor to have a new alias, use AdvResultSetMetaData.clone(String newAlias) on your existing metadata.
(mainly useful for cloning)

Parameters:
list - a List of AdvTuples
metadata - Metadata suitable for those tuples
operImpl - the OperatorImplementation to be used in this cursor (or null for default)

AdvTupleCursor

public AdvTupleCursor(Cursor<?> cur,
                      java.lang.String alias)
A constructor that an AdvTupleCursor from a nonempty Cursor of arbitrary type
Don't use this Constructor for Cursors containing Tuples (e.g. from a join)! We have a factory Method (factorFromCursorWithAdvTuples() ) for that purpose that is safer, especially with empty cursors (like from a join creating an empty cursor because the Predicate is never met).
The Cursor will contain Tuples with one column named "value" that containing the elements of cur

Parameters:
cur - Cursor to be wrapped
alias - an Alias

The first element of the cursor will be inspected (vie peek()) to generate the mapping from the elements to AdvTuple - this will of course fail if there are no elements to peek.

AdvTupleCursor

public AdvTupleCursor(java.sql.ResultSet resultset,
                      java.lang.String alias)
Wraps a ResultSet (most probably from JDBC, i.e. from a query to a database) into an AdvTupleCursor.
By default it does not cache its tuples - its AdvTupleCursor.CachingStrategy is set to NONE in contrast to most other constructors that set an ONLY_FIRST caching strategy.
That's because ResultSets can contain a lot of elements and creating Tuples from them is quite easy. You may change this setting via setCachingStrategy(), of course.

Parameters:
resultset - the ResultSet to be wrapped
alias - the alias of the AdvTupleCursor created

AdvTupleCursor

public AdvTupleCursor(java.sql.ResultSet resultset,
                      java.lang.String alias,
                      OperatorImplementation operImpl)
Wraps a ResultSet (most probably from JDBC, i.e. from a query to a database) into an AdvTupleCursor.
By default it does not cache its tuples - its AdvTupleCursor.CachingStrategy is set to NONE in contrast to most other constructors that set an ONLY_FIRST caching strategy.
That's because ResultSets can contain a lot of elements and creating Tuples from them is quite easy. You may change this setting via setCachingStrategy(), of course.

Parameters:
resultset - the ResultSet to be wrapped

operImpl - the OperatorImplementation to be used in this cursor (or null for default)
Method Detail

automagicallyCreateTupleCursor

public static AdvTupleCursor automagicallyCreateTupleCursor(java.lang.Iterable<?> it,
                                                            java.lang.String alias)
This factory creates an AdvTupleCursor for Iterables (Lists, ...) containing arbitrary types and does an "automagical" mapping:
  • If the elements are Objects of a primitive type (or pseudo-Primitive like Integer, String, ...) the Tuples in the resulting Cursor will just contain one element called "value".
  • If the elements contain a more complex type, the public(!) getters (get*() and is*()) will be used to obtain values. The columns will be called according to the getter: The value retrieved from getFoo() will be in the column "foo".
  • If the elements are Arrays (of equal length!), value i from the array (arr[i]) will be value i+1 in the Tuple (because tuples start counting at 1) and will be called with i >= 1 (e.g. "col1" or "col42")

Parameters:
it - an Iterable providing the elements
alias - an Alias for the created AdvTupleCursor
Returns:
an AdvTupleCursor wrapping it

automagicallyCreateTupleCursor

public static AdvTupleCursor automagicallyCreateTupleCursor(java.util.Iterator<?> it,
                                                            java.lang.String alias)
This factory creates an AdvTupleCursor for Iterators/Cursors containing arbitrary types and does an "automagical" mapping:
  • If the elements are Objects of a primitive type (or pseudo-Primitive like Integer, String, ...) the Tuples in the resulting Cursor will just contain one element called "value".
  • If the elements contain a more complex type, the public(!) getters (get*() and is*()) will be used to obtain values. The columns will be called according to the getter: The value retrieved from getFoo() will be in the column "foo".
  • If the elements are Arrays (of equal length!), value i from the array (arr[i]) will be value i+1 in the Tuple (because tuples start counting at 1) and will be called with i >= 1 (e.g. "col1" or "col42")

Parameters:
it - an Iterator/Cursor providing the elements
alias - an Alias for the created AdvTupleCursor
Returns:
an AdvTupleCursor wrapping it

Creates a Tuple from an Object using the mapping function objToTuple

o - an Object
Returns:
a Tuple created from that Object

factorFromCursorWithTuples

public static AdvTupleCursor factorFromCursorWithTuples(Cursor<Tuple> cur,
                                                        AdvResultSetMetaData metadata,
                                                        AdvTupleCursor... parents)
Factory Function that wraps a Cursor containing AdvTuples (e.g. from a join, ...) to an AdvTupleCursor.
If you want this to have a specific new alias, make sure your metadata already has got it (via AdvResultSetMetaData.clone(String newAlias) or AdvResultSetMetaData.concat(AdvResultSetMetaData first, AdvResultSetMetaData second, String newAlias).
The parents is/are the AdvTupleCursor(s) providing the tuples processed by this cursor.
Example: cur1.join(cur2, col("x").EQ(col("y"), "foo").where(col("z").LEQ(val(4711))) cur1 and cur2 are the parents of the cursor returned by join, which itself is the parent of the cursor returned by where.

Parameters:
cur - the Cursor to be wrapped
metadata - appropriate Metadata for the AdvTuples
parents - "parents" of this cursor (if any)
Returns:
an AdvTupleCursor containing the elements of cur

internal_sort

protected void internal_sort(java.util.Comparator<Tuple> comp)
Sorts Cursor this by the given comperator. (useful for sorting and grouping)
The Cursor will be reset! (Wouldn't make much sense not to reset anyway..)

Parameters:
comp - the Comparator

hasNextObject

protected boolean hasNextObject()
Description copied from class: AbstractCursor
Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

This abstract operation should implement the core functionality of the hasNext method which secures that the cursor is in a proper state when this method is called. Due to this the hasNextObject method need not to deal with exception handling.

Specified by:
hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<Tuple>
Returns:
true if the cursor has more elements.

nextObject

protected Tuple nextObject()
Description copied from class: AbstractCursor
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the cursor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

This abstract operation should implement the core functionality of the next method which secures that the cursor is in a proper state when this method is called. Due to this the nextObject method need not to deal with exception handling.

Specified by:
nextObject in class AbstractCursor<Tuple>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.

reset

public void reset()
           throws java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
Description copied from class: AbstractCursor
Resets the cursor to its initial state such that the caller is able to traverse the underlying data structure again without constructing a new cursor (optional operation). The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying data structure, are still persistent.

Note, that this operation is optional and does not work for this cursor.

The current implementation of this method is as follows: 

   public void reset() throws IllegalStateException,
                              UnsupportedOperationException {
       if (!supportsReset())
           throw new UnsupportedOperationException();
       hasNext = false;
       computedHasNext = false;
       isValid = false;
       assignedNext = false;
   }

Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor<Tuple>
Overrides:
reset in class AbstractCursor<Tuple>
Throws:
java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the cursor.

supportsReset

public boolean supportsReset()
Description copied from class: AbstractCursor
Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the cursor. Otherwise it returns false.

The current implementation of this method is as follows: 

   public boolean supportsReset() {
       return false;
   }

Specified by:
supportsReset in interface Cursor<Tuple>
Overrides:
supportsReset in class AbstractCursor<Tuple>
Returns:
true if the reset operation is supported by the cursor, otherwise false.

iterator

public java.util.Iterator<Tuple> iterator()
Returns this Cursor (as it is itself an Iterator containing Tuples).
If it has already been used it will be reset() before being returned to make sure the returned Iterator iterates all Tuples of this Cursor.
It doesn't make to much sense to use this Method directly, but it enables for-each loops for this class.
Example: 
 AdvTupleCursors cur = ... ; // some AdvTupleCursor
 for(Tuple tup : cur){
        System.out.println(tup);
 }
Note: It is not possible to nest two of this iterators from the same cursor (or if one cursor is a part of the other cursor). This means, the following will produce strange behavior: 
 AdvTupleCursors cur1 = ... ; // some AdvTupleCursor
 AdvTupleCursor cur2 = cur1.where(...); // cur2 contains cur1!
 for(Tuple t1 : cur1){
        for(Tuple t2 : cur2) {
                System.out.println(t1+" "+t2);
        }
 }
If you want something like this you have to Object.clone()!

Specified by:
iterator in interface java.lang.Iterable<Tuple>
Returns:
an Iterator containing Tuples, i.e. this

clone

public AdvTupleCursor clone(java.lang.String alias)
Returns a clone of this Cursor with given Alias. Will fail if this cursor does not support reset() And it will reset your cursor!.
This is especially useful for self-joins: joining a cursor with itself (or a query that shares some cursors with this one like AdvTupleCursors atc1 = cur1.where(...); AdvTupleCursor atc2 = cur1.select(...);) is impossible (or rather: it is possible, but you'll get strange results).
But if you clone the cursors before joining it'll work.
Example: 
 AdvTupleCursor cur1 = ...; // a AdvTupleCursor
 AdvTupleCursor atc1 = cur1.where(...);
 AdvTupleCursor atc2 = cur1.clone("cur1clone").select(...);
 AdvTupleCursor join = atc1.join(atc2, col("cur1.a").LEQ(col("cur1clone.b")));

Parameters:
alias - an Alias
Returns:
a clone of this Cursor

addCorrTuplesRec

public void addCorrTuplesRec(CorrTuplesReceiver ctr)
Add a "correlated Tuple Receiver" to the Cursors corrTuplesReceivers list. That's a list of Objects implementing CorrTuplesReceiver (atm only Predicates from WHERE).
In this list all CorrTupleReceivers of this Query (this Cursor and it's parents) are collected so EXISTS etc can set the correlated Tuples in the Predicates of their (possibly correlated) subqueries.

Parameters:
ctr - A "Corrolated Tuples Receiver", for example an AdvPredicate
See Also:
AdvPredicate.setCorrelatedTuples(List)

getCorrTuplesRec

public java.util.List<CorrTuplesReceiver> getCorrTuplesRec()
Returns a list of Objects implementing CorrTuplesReceiver (atm only Predicates from WHERE).
In this list all CorrTupleReceivers of this Query (this Cursor and it's parents) are collected so EXISTS etc can set the correlated Tuples in the Predicates of their (possibly correlated) subqueries.

Returns:
a List of "Corrolated Tuples Receivers", for example AdvPredicates
See Also:
AdvPredicate.setCorrelatedTuples(List)

setCachingStrategy

public void setCachingStrategy(AdvTupleCursor.CachingStrategy strat,
                               boolean recursive)
Sets the AdvTupleCursor.CachingStrategy for this cursor and maybe its parental cursors (if recursive is true). The CachingStrategy determines whether the cursor saves its tuples in an intern list in the first run, so it doesn't have to compute them again after reset().
Settings recursive to false doesn't make too much sense for the SMART strategies, however: if this cursor is a join/difference/intersection, the right parent's caching will be enabled.
See AdvTupleCursor.CachingStrategy for an extensive explanation of the different strategies and what they're good for.

Parameters:
strat - the AdvTupleCursor.CachingStrategy to be set
recursive - if true, this strategy will also be set to the parental cursors
See Also:
AdvTupleCursor.CachingStrategy

getCachingStrategy

public AdvTupleCursor.CachingStrategy getCachingStrategy()
Returns the CachingStrategy of this cursor. See AdvTupleCursor.CachingStrategy for an extensive explanation of the different strategies and what they're good for.

Returns:
this cursor's caching strategy

setOperatorImpl

public void setOperatorImpl(OperatorImplementation impl)
Sets a custom implementation of operators (join, where, ...) for this query, e.g. for this cursor, its parents, their parents, ...
If you don't want to change the implementation for the whole query but only for this cursor use setOperatorImpl(impl, false)

Parameters:
impl - the alternative implementation of operators

setOperatorImpl

public void setOperatorImpl(OperatorImplementation impl,
                            boolean recursive)
Sets a custom implementation of operators (join, where, ...) for this cursor.
If recursive is true it's set for the whole query, if not just for this cursor.

Parameters:
impl - the alternative implementation of operators
recursive - if true it will be set in the whole query, else just for this cursor

createAndSetMetaDataFromClass

protected static MapEntry<java.util.List<java.lang.reflect.Method>,AdvResultSetMetaData> createAndSetMetaDataFromClass(java.lang.Class<?> cl,
                                                                                                                       java.lang.String alias)
Automagically sets creates and sets MetaData and a list of getters in this Cursor for Objects of the given Class.
The mapping itself should be created with createDefaultMapping() and will use the list of getters created by this Method.
If cl is a (pseudo)-primitive type (Float, Integer, ... , Boolean, Byte, Character, String) the tuples will have only one column named "value".
If the class it is not primitive, it will be scanned for getters and for each getter there will be a column with the getters suffix, the first character will be lowercase (i.e. the column for "getFoo()" will be called "foo").

Parameters:
cl - the type of the Objects this Cursor is to wrap
alias - this Cursor's alias
See Also:
AdvTupleCursor#createDefaultMapping()

getObjectType

protected static java.lang.Class getObjectType(java.lang.Class<?> type)
Returns the Object-type for a primitive type (or just the given type if it isn't primitive)

Parameters:
type - a type/class, that might be primitive
Returns:
the according non-primitive type

createDefaultMapping

Returns a function that creates a tuple from an Object. Needs MetaData and the getters-list that may be generated with createAndSetMetaDataFromClass(Class, String)

concatTuples

public static Tuple concatTuples(Tuple t1,
                                 Tuple t2,
                                 int size1,
                                 int size2)
Returns a Tuple that is a concatenation of the given Tuples. Useful for join().

Parameters:
t1 - first Tuple (if null, all columns will be null for outer join)
t2 - second Tuple (if null, all columns will be null for outer join)
size1 - number of colums in the first tuple
size2 - number of colums in the second tuple
Returns:
t1++t2

select

public AdvTupleCursor select(Column... columns)
Like the SQL SELECT clause. You can select existing Columns from this cursor (with col()) or create new ones by combining existing Columns (for example with Column.ADD(Column, String)) or getting values via reflection from existing Columns (for example with ColumnUtils#colOBJCALL() or even insert new static values with ColumnUtils.val(Object, String).

Parameters:
columns - Columns you want to select/create
Returns:
an AdvTupleCursor containing the selected/created Columns

Parameters:
columns - Columns you want to select/create
Returns:
an AdvTupleCursor containing the selected/created Columns

where

public AdvTupleCursor where(AdvPredicate predicate)
Filters the tuples by the given predicate. If the predicate evaluates to true for a tuple it's contained in the resulting cursor, if it does not it isn't contained.

Parameters:
predicate - the predicate of the filter
Returns:
the filtered cursor

union

public AdvTupleCursor union(AdvTupleCursor other)
Unions this cursor with another cursor. The cursors need to have the same schema, i.e. the column count needs to be identical and the names and types of each column need to be identical.

Parameters:
other - the cursor to be unioned with
Returns:
a cursor containing the tuples of both this cursor and the other cursor

Returns:

groupBy

public AdvTupleCursor groupBy(Column[] group,
                              AggregateColumn... aggregations)
Groups the Cursor by the given Columns and performs the given aggregations. The resulting cursor's tuples will contain the Columns from group and the new columns created by the aggregations. The Colums to be grouped need to map to an index within the tuples, i.e. you may not use val() or reflection Columns here. If you want to group by values obtained by reflection you have to insert them into the tuple with select(cols) first!
Note: To conveniently specify the Columns to be grouped by you may use ColumnUtils.PROJ(Column...) so you don't have to create an Array yourself.

Parameters:
group - the Columns to be grouped by (use ColumnUtils.PROJ(Column...))
aggregations - aggregations (like count, avg, ...) to be performed on the cursor
Returns:
a cursor containing the Columns from group and the new columns created by the aggregations.
See Also:
ColumnUtils.PROJ(Column...)

groupBy

public AdvTupleCursor groupBy(java.lang.String alias,
                              Column[] group,
                              AggregateColumn... aggregations)
Groups the Cursor by the given Columns and performs the given aggregations. The resulting cursor's tuples will contain the Columns from group and the new columns created by the aggregations. The Colums to be grouped need to map to an index within the tuples, i.e. you may not use val() or reflection Columns here. If you want to group by values obtained by reflection you have to insert them into the tuple with select(cols) first!
Note: To conveniently specify the Columns to be grouped by you may use ColumnUtils.PROJ(Column...) so you don't have to create an Array yourself.

Parameters:
alias - the new alias for the resulting cursor
group - the Columns to be grouped by (use ColumnUtils.PROJ(Column...))
aggregations - aggregations (like count, avg, ...) to be performed on the cursor
Returns:
a cursor containing the Columns from group and the new columns created by the aggregations.
See Also:
ColumnUtils.PROJ(Column...)

distinct

public AdvTupleCursor distinct()
Eliminates duplicate Tuples

Returns:
a cursor containing the same tuples as this cursor, but each tuple only once

difference

public AdvTupleCursor difference(AdvTupleCursor other,
                                 boolean all)
Removes tuples from this cursor that are contained in the other cursor.
The cursors need to have the same schema, i.e. the column count needs to be identical and the names and types of each column need to be identical.
If all is true, all tuples from this cursor that are contained in the other one are removed, else only as many tuples of each set of duplicate tuples are removed as are returned in the other cursor.
Example: if this cursor contains 3 tuples ("a", "b", "c") and the other cursor contains one tuple ("a", "b", "c"), the resulting cursor will contain 2 tuples ("a", "b", "c") if all is false or no tuple ("a", "b", "c") if all is true.

Parameters:
other - the cursor that is subtracted from this one
all - see above
Returns:
a cursor containing only elements not contained in the other cursor (if all is true) or containing less elements that are also contained in the other cursor (if all is false)

difference

public AdvTupleCursor difference(AdvTupleCursor other)
Removes all tuples from this cursor that are contained in the other cursor.
The cursors need to have the same schema, i.e. the column count needs to be identical and the names and types of each column need to be identical.

Parameters:
other - the cursor that is subtracted from this one
Returns:
a cursor containing elements that are contained in this cursor, but not in the other cursor

intersect

public AdvTupleCursor intersect(AdvTupleCursor other)
Calculates an intersection of this cursor and the other cursor, i.e. the resulting cursor will only contain elements contained in this cursor and the other cursor.
The cursors need to have the same schema, i.e. the column count needs to be identical and the names and types of each column need to be identical.

Parameters:
other - the cursor this one is intersected with
Returns:
a cursor containing only elements contained in both this and the other cursor

orderBy

public AdvTupleCursor orderBy(Column... cols)
Sorts the Tuples of this cursor by the given Columns in ascending order.
It is sorted by the order of the Columns: It's sorted primary by the first Column, secundarily by the second Column and so on.

Parameters:
cols - Columns to sort by
Returns:
a sorted Cursor
See Also:
orderBy(asc, cols) if you want to order in descending order

orderBy

public AdvTupleCursor orderBy(boolean asc,
                              Column... cols)
Sorts the Tuples of this cursor by the given Columns.
It is sorted by the order of the Columns: It's sorted primary by the first Column, secundarily by the second Column and so on.

Parameters:
asc - if false the cursor will be sorted in descending order, else ascending
cols - Columns to sort by
Returns:
a sorted Cursor

Parameters:
count - how many tuples to be returned
Returns:
an AdvTupleCursor returning the count first elements of this cursor

getIterableForColumn

public java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Object> getIterableForColumn(Column col)
Returns an Iterable for one column of this Cursor. This may be used in a for-each loop.
Example: 
 List l1; // a list of Foos
 // a query on that list, for example using reflection, maybe joining 
 // some other cursor, doesn't matter...
 AdvTupleCursor cur = new AdvTupleCursor(l1, "l1")
                .where( colOBJCALL(col("l1.value"), "getA").LEQ(val(42)) )
                .join(...);
 // now I want the elements from l1 that are left after that query
 for( Object o : cur.getIterableForColumn(col("l1.value")) ){
                Foo f = (Foo)o;
                f.someMethod();
 }
 Note: It is not possible to nest two of this iterators from the same cursor (or if one cursor is a part of the other cursor). This means, the following will produce strange behavior: 
 AdvTupleCursors cur1 = ... ; // some AdvTupleCursor
 AdvTupleCursor cur2 = cur1.where(...); // cur2 contains cur1!
 for( Tuple t1 : cur1.getIterableForColumn(col("a")) ){
        for( Tuple t2 : cur2.getIterableForColumn(col("b")) ) {
                System.out.println(t1+" "+t2);
        }
 }
If you want something like this you have to Object.clone()!

public AdvTupleCursor expand(Column col)
